title: 111_s2983
content: The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" allows for payroll tax forgiveness for hiring unemployed workers. The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" provides a special exemption for certain individuals hired in 2010, allowing qualified employers to not apply subsection (a) of Section 3111 of the Internal Revenue Code to wages paid to qualified individuals for services performed during a specific period. The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" exempts qualified employers from certain taxes when hiring qualified individuals, defined as individuals who are not employed by the United States, any State, any local government, or any instrumentality of the foregoing. The term 'qualified individual' refers to an individual who starts working for a qualified employer between February 3, 2010, and January 1, 2011, certifies they have not worked more than 40 hours in the 60 days before starting, and is not replacing another employee unless that employee left voluntarily. The text discusses the option for a qualified employer to elect not to apply a certain subsection, with coordination with the Work Opportunity Credit also mentioned. The text discusses the exclusion of wages for qualified individuals from payroll tax forgiveness unless the employer elects not to apply a certain subsection. Appropriations are made to the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Trust Fund and the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund. The amendments made by this section apply to wages paid after the enactment of the Act. Amounts equal to the reduction in revenues to the Treasury by the amendments shall be appropriated to the Survivors Trust Fund and the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund. SEC. 3. Business credit for retention of certain newly hired individuals in 2010. The current year business credit for taxable years after the enactment of this Act will increase by $1,000 for each retained worker who meets certain criteria. A retained worker is a qualified individual employed by the taxpayer during the taxable year. The current year business credit will increase by $1,000 for each retained worker who meets specific criteria: employed by the taxpayer for at least 52 consecutive weeks, with wages in the last 26 weeks equaling 80% of the first 26 weeks.
